channel.title: Confessions of a Pioneer Woman | Ree Drummond - Full RSS Feed

item.title: Last Day
item.dc:creator: Ree
item.description: First of all…   Luke’s photo is the winner of the Instagram contest!       Congratulations, Luke.       Matt, your horse photo was awesome. You were a very worthy opponent!       So was your grill photo, Mike! I’ll stop shouting now! Sheesh, Ree!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Sorry. Anyway, the guys will all be hightailing it back to England soon. I’ll miss the ol’ chaps. But I’m going to be happy not to wear…
item.content:encoded:
First of all…

 
Luke’s photo is the winner of the Instagram contest!

 
 
 
Congratulations, Luke.

 
 
 
Matt, your horse photo was awesome. You were a very worthy opponent!

 
 
 
So was your grill photo, Mike!

I’ll stop shouting now!

Sheesh, Ree!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Sorry.

Anyway, the guys will all be hightailing it back to England soon.

I’ll miss the ol’ chaps.

But I’m going to be happy not to wear a mic for awhile. I’d like to go to the bathroom without unplugging first.

Sometimes I get stage fright.

You don’t want to know any more than that.

 
 
 
Yesterday I shot an entire show in one day, which is unusual. Typically, episodes take 1 1/2 to 2 days to shoot, but this one was basically shoot-as-it-happens. It was a freezer meal theme: I filled the freezer with lots of yummy food for busy days in my house, which is every day, and man, am I excited to have all this grub.

*Burp*

 
 
 
Here, Mike is rigging the freezer door so it won’t keep hitting me on the bottom as I stand and describe some of the things I’d stocked the freezer with.

It was getting a little embarrassing.

“This is a great freezer casserole. Really great flavor…” WHAP! The door hit me on the bottom.

“One thing I like to do is store grilled chicken breasts in airtight bags…” WHAP! The door hit me on the bottom.

“This is one of my favorite freezer soups. To make it, you…” WHAP! The door hit me on the bottom.

This is just another behind-the-scenes wrinkle you never think about when you watch cooking shows on TV: Freezer doors hitting the person on the bottom every time they try to talk.

It’s one of those things no one ever talks about.

 
 
This is my precious firstborn son. He makes my heart leap. I’ve been making him and his brother come hang out in my dressing room so I can listen to them talk about football and accuse them of eating all my snacks.

Man, can they polish off some snacks. Like, whole packages. Gone. Poof. As if the snacks ever existed.

 
 
 
I make Charlie come hang out in my dressing room, too.

 
 
 
It’s nice to walk in there and get a nice whiff of hound funk anytime I need a little pick-me-up.

Really keeps me going.

Or…not.

Have a happy Tuesday, everyone!

item.title: Eggs in Hash Brown Nests
item.dc:creator: Ree
item.description: These are the perfect little side dish for Easter Brunch: Tender-but-crispy potato nests with a luscious baked egg in the middle. They go perfectly with ham for a more substantial brunch, or they’re great for a casual breakfast with a piece of bacon. Or two. Or three. Or nineteen. I will say, when I first decided to try these out, I was excited. I’d seen different iterations of the little cutie-pies and I figured they’d…
item.content:encoded:
These are the perfect little side dish for Easter Brunch: Tender-but-crispy potato nests with a luscious baked egg in the middle. They go perfectly with ham for a more substantial brunch, or they’re great for a casual breakfast with a piece of bacon. Or two. Or three. Or nineteen.

I will say, when I first decided to try these out, I was excited. I’d seen different iterations of the little cutie-pies and I figured they’d be a piece of cake to whip up. But in fact, I had to go through quite a bit of trial and error before I cracked the dang code. And by the time I figured it all out, I think I’d shaved a good seven months off of my life expectancy.

I started off trying frozen hash brown potatoes, which I initially assumed would work fine. But they wound up being way, way too dry: During the initial baking of the nest, they shriveled to almost nothing, and after the egg baked inside the nests, the hash browns turned a very strange consistency—and there was hardly any potato flavor at all. Super dry, super weird.

Frozen Hash Browns = A no-go for this recipe. Like, totally.

After giving up on the frozen potatoes, I wound up fiddling with fresh potatoes in a couple of different ways: First I tried grating them from a raw state, which didn’t work at all. Too mushy. Didn’t crisp up. Produced angst. Made me crazy.

Finally, the best result came from grating almost-fully-baked potatoes: The consistency was perfect and the potato flavor was fabulous.

Then I slept for a month because I was so exhausted.

It would be a long, long time before I’d be able to trust again.

 
 
Here’s how to make them! Start by baking a few potatoes. I scrubbed the potatoes, then baked them until they were not quite tender enough to eat: Soft, but with the tiniest bit of bite left. This will make them easier to grate, and will also allow more room for baking later.

 
 
 
I let them cool almost completely (you could bake the potatoes Saturday night and keep them in the fridge), then peeled them with a paring knife.

 
 
 
Grate all the potatoes, using the largest grating size. As you grate them, if you hear just a tiny bit of “crunch” signifying that the potato isn’t fully cooked, that’s just fine, Maynard.

Sorry I called you Maynard.

Next, season the potatoes generously with salt and pepper: Just toss them around with your hands as you sprinkle.

 
 
 
Spray a muffin pan lightly with a little cooking spray…

 
 
 
Then drop a small amount (a little less than 1/4 cup) into each muffin cup.

 
 
 
Use your fingers to lightly press the center so that the potatoes spill over the top a bit. They’ll shrink when they bake, so don’t be afraid to really spill over the top.

 
 
 
Sprinkle on a tiny bit more salt and pepper…

 
 
 
Then give the tops just a very light spray again.

 
 
 
Bake them for about 20-25 minutes (note the increased oven temp in printable recipe below) until they’re golden brown. Keep an eye on them so the ends of the potato shreds don’t burn.

You can see how much the potatoes shrink up!

 
 
 
Now, I let the nests cool a bit (you can even bake them off an hour or two ahead of time and let them totally cool) before cracking in the eggs.

 
 
 
Let the eggs bake for 10-15 minutes, until they get to the level of doneness you’re looking for. I still like to have a little softness to the yolks, and mine baked for probably 12 minutes or so.

* Note: Be assured that no matter what, all of your eggs will probably bake a little differently and won’t all look exactly the same on top. Some whites will look perfect, some might look a little funky. Some whites will cover the yolk, some will gloriously reveal the yolk.

But that’s the beauty of these things! They’re rustic.

Ha.

 
 
 
These are great with Easter Ham (I’ll post the recipe here next)! If you feel like you need a little practice before Sunday, you can pare down the amounts and do a practice run with one potato and two or three eggs. The instructions are the same whether you make a big batch or a small one.

These are totally delicious. My family loves them. My brother-in-law Tim likes to douse them with hot sauce. (I have to admit, I do too.)

Here’s the handy printable:

Recipe

Eggs in Hash Brown Nests

Prep Time:
15 Minutes
Cook Time:
1 Hour30 Minutes
Difficulty:
Easy
Servings:
12
Print Recipe

Ingredients

  • 6 whole Medium Russet Potatoes (6 To 8)
  • Salt And Pepper, to taste
  • 24 whole Large Eggs
  • Non-stick Cooking Spray

Preparation Instructions

Preheat the oven to 400 degrees.

Bake the potatoes until almost tender (potatoes should still have a little bite) 45 minutes to 1 hour. Allow to cool, and then peel and grate them. Season well with salt and pepper.

INCREASE OVEN TEMP TO 425 DEGREES.

Spray two muffin pans generously with cooking spray. Scoop 3 to 4 tablespoons of grated potato into each muffin cup. Use your fingers to gently press the sides and bottom in each muffin hole to make a nest (don't press the potatoes firmly against the pan; they should sit lightly in the pan.) Spray again (very lightly!) with cooking spray. Bake for 15 to 20 minutes. Watch and make sure they do not burn. (If they seem like they're not browning, kick up the temp to 450.) Remove when the nests are golden brown.

Allow the nests to cool. Crack an egg into each one. Sprinkle with salt and pepper and bake until the whites are set, about 15 minutes. Don't be concerned if some whites bake differently; no two nests will look alike!

Remove from the muffin pan with a spoon or fork and serve.

Posted by Ree on March 26 2013

item.title: Women of the Frontier
item.dc:creator: OMSH
item.category: Book ReviewsContributorsEnglish/LiteratureHistory/GeographyHomeschooling MaterialsOMSHAmerican History Readerspioneer womenWestward Expansionwestward movement
item.description: By Heather Sanders. There are only 6 weeks left in our co-op’s school year, and Kenny has blazed through 19 of the 25 readers purchased or borrowed for his American History course. Now that he is studying the Westward Movement, he and I both realized we failed to collect a single reader about the Americans who felt it was their “Manifest Destiny” to Go West, settling the continent from the Atlantic to Pacific Oceans. Imagine…
item.content:encoded:
By Heather Sanders.

There are only 6 weeks left in our co-op’s school year, and Kenny has blazed through 19 of the 25 readers purchased or borrowed for his American History course.

Now that he is studying the Westward Movement, he and I both realized we failed to collect a single reader about the Americans who felt it was their “Manifest Destiny” to Go West, settling the continent from the Atlantic to Pacific Oceans.

Imagine my excitement at the timing when Chicago Review Press sent a copy of the newest release in their Women of Action series, Women of the Frontier: 16 Tales of Trailblazing, Homesteaders, Entrepreneurs, and Rabble-Rousers by Brandon Marie Miller.

March is Women’s History Month, and I realize that means I’m a little late on the draw as we are steadfastly heading into April. Still, when I find a good book I like to share it, and this book completely captures the courage of the pioneering women of the mid-1800s.

Kenny couldn’t help but be interested in it after seeing me take it to bed three nights in a row. The first chapter about how Margret Reed survived starvation near Lake Truckee in the Sierra Nevada sucked him in immediately. From missionaries and physicians to naturalists and suffragettes, the stories are taken directly from the “ordinary lives of daughters, sisters, wives, and mothers.”

Miller weaves this collection of abridged biographies, period photos, letters home, and even song lyrics so artfully that I finished wanting to know more about each of their personal lives. Trekking 2,000 miles across a seemingly endless frontier, these 19th century women were hard core, leaving behind friends and family they would likely never see again, for the hope of a better life.

The sufferings endured on the wagon train often did not ease up after arriving at their destination; at that point, the pioneer women learned to meet their challenges, fears and setbacks with perseverance and determination as they worked side-by-side with their husbands to build log cabins or sod houses, work the land, mills, stores, or inns, all while caring for children, pregnancy, and bearing/raising babies.

While some of the women adapted more readily than others, most of their writing reveals their appreciation for the rugged beauty they came to see in the new landscape of their lives.

Targeted for middle school students ages 12 and up, Brandon Marie Miller’s Women of the Frontier: 16 Tales of Trailblazing, Homesteaders, Entrepreneurs, and Rabble-Rousers is a wonderful supplement to any study of American History and the Westward Movement.

Are you a fan of stories from this period? Any Westward Movement reader recommendations for middle school and up?

 

OMSH/Heather L. Sanders is a wife, mother and friend. She is also a Homeschooling Blogger and Writer. Balance is the challenge she rises to each and every morning.

item.title: The Family That Photobombs Together…
item.dc:creator: Ree
item.description: First: I shared this photo of my youngest child on PW Home & Garden this morning. In that post, I’m featuring the groovy bow tie he’s wearing. But in this post, I’m just showing you the photo because I love it.     I’m showing you this one for the same reason. Wait. Did you hear that? Did you hear that noise? That was my heart going pitter-pat. Boys wearing bow ties will do that…
item.content:encoded:
First: I shared this photo of my youngest child on PW Home & Garden this morning. In that post, I’m featuring the groovy bow tie he’s wearing. But in this post, I’m just showing you the photo because I love it.

 
 
I’m showing you this one for the same reason.

Wait. Did you hear that?

Did you hear that noise?

That was my heart going pitter-pat.

Boys wearing bow ties will do that to a mama.

In other news: I just have a day or so of shooting left, which means I’m about 24 hours away from not showering, not wearing makeup, not drying or styling my hair, and not caring what my fingernails look like.

Get ready, Marlboro Man! You’re gonna love it.

Or not.

 
 
In related news: This is me putting on my ninetieth coat of mascara.

I would like to report, however, that I have been using brown eyeliner instead of black during this shoot. It’s been hard to step away from the Pat Benetar look, but my soul tells me brown makes more logical sense with my red hair and pigmentless skin.

But man, am I caking on that brown eyeliner. I won’t go down without a fight!

 
 
On the food front: Last week I made cookies.

 
 
 
And puh-tay-tuh chips!

 
 
 
And a sandwich that made the ingesters of the sandwiches very happy.

Is ingesters a word? I’m thinking it isn’t.

 
 
 
During the course of the shoots, the boot room at the Lodge has turned into a little bit of a makeshift kitchen/extra prep area. The boots are running out of patience and are getting ready to stage a coup.

“You city slicker sheet pans have exactly one hour to git outta this here town…”

 
 
 
Matt snapped this photo. Bruiser Pookie Sunshine Of My Life loves having the crew here, but he especially loves Matt. Matt has two terriers back in England and he loves on Bruiser every day because he misses his doggies.

Please look at how Bruiser is sitting.

And speaking of Matt: Matt, Luke, and Mike (the camera and lighting guys on the shoot) are friends on Instagram, and they often post photos and comment on one another’s shots. More than once, I have witnessed some ribbing (read: trash-talking) going on about whose Instagram photos are better.

So I asked each of them to send me one of their favorite Instagram photos of the ranch. Then I asked them if they’d mind if I posted them here.

Then I asked them if they’d mind if I turned it into a contest.

They all said fine.

So here they are!

 
Matt.

 
 
Mike.

 
 
Luke.

Here’s the ballot! I’ll post the winner tomorrow.

 

Matt, Mike, or Luke?

 
 
Here, Nicole, Mike, and Olivia are discussing the lighting and setup for the recipe I’m about to shoot.

 
 
 
Here, I’ve taken a few steps closer and Mike and Olivia are trying to pretend I’m not there.

 
 
 
I love Olivia’s smile!

 
 
 
The other day, Marlboro Man, the kids, and Josh came up for lunch and I tried to get a shot of my beloved. It’s difficult to do these days, because my two teenage daughters are going through a phase wherein they believe photobombing is the most hilarious thing in the world.

Just keep your eye on that tall kid in the background.

 
 
 
See?

 
 
 
Photobombing is kind of funny.

But I think it’s even funnier when the perpetrator gets caught.

 
 
Nobody photobombs a cowboy and gets away with it.

 
 
 
Not even the cowboy’s own daughter.

 
 
 
The family that photobombs together stays together.

At least I think that’s how the saying goes.

item.title: Krispy Easter Eggs
item.dc:creator: Ree
item.description: Imagine the Easter Bunny laying an egg. Wait. That’s not anatomically possible. And anyway, the Easter Bunny is a boy, right? It’s even more impossible than I thought! Okay, let’s start this whole thing over. Imagine that the Easter Bunny’s wife is a chicken, and imagine her laying an egg. These sweet, crispy eggs with a fun candy surprise inside would be what came out! Wait. I don’t think that’s possible either. Sheesh. Leave it…
item.content:encoded:
Imagine the Easter Bunny laying an egg.

Wait. That’s not anatomically possible.

And anyway, the Easter Bunny is a boy, right? It’s even more impossible than I thought!

Okay, let’s start this whole thing over. Imagine that the Easter Bunny’s wife is a chicken, and imagine her laying an egg. These sweet, crispy eggs with a fun candy surprise inside would be what came out!

Wait. I don’t think that’s possible either.

Sheesh. Leave it to me to take something as innocent as an Easter treat and turn it into something disturbing. Please don’t let me spoil this special time for you.

Haunting visuals aside, these adorable little ovoid (vocabulary word alert!) wonders are nothing more than Rice Kripie Treats that have been thrown into a wacky-looking Easter egg machine and, minutes later, come out the other end looking like Easter eggs. They’re super easy and fun to make with kids. The perfect Easter treat!

 
 
 
Add the butter to a pot or large saucepan and melt it over medium heat.

 
 
 
Throw in a bag of mini-marshmallows…

 
 
 
And stir it until the marshmallows are melty and sinful.

 
 
 
Throw in 6 cups of Rice Krispies…

 
 
 
And stir it around gently until it’s all sticky and gooey and combined.

 
 
 
Next, lightly spray the inside of a plastic Easter egg with cooking spray.

You know. Those plastic Easter eggs? The ones you think are taking over your house one minute, then the next minute, when you actually need them to photograph a recipe, you can’t find one to save your life so you drive over to your sister-in-law’s house and borrow hers?

Yes, those plastic Easter eggs.

 
 
 
Stuff one half with the Rice Krispie mixture, then press a chocolate egg into the center. (The official Rice Krispie recipe calls for hollowing out a well and placing small candies in the center, but my motto is “Go Big Chocolate Easter Egg or Go Home.”)

 
 
 
Fill the other half of the egg with more cereal mixture, then press the two halves together until they’re totally closed. The egg should be full enough to meet with a little resistance as you close the egg, but not so full that you feel like you’re crushing the life out of the cereal.

 
 
 
A few seconds later, gently pull the egg out of…well, the egg! I found that the longer you let them sit in the plastic eggs, the harder it was to get out.

 
 
 
Sprinkle them with different springy colors of sprinkles, and place them in an egg holder to let them set.

 
 
 
Let the kids do this part!

Just have a broom nearby.

 
 
 
Lovely and adorable.

Recipe

Krispy Easter Eggs

Prep Time:
20 Minutes
Cook Time:
5 Minutes
Difficulty:
Easy
Servings:
12
Print Recipe

Ingredients

  • 4 Tablespoons Butter
  • 1 package (10 Ounces) Mini Marshmallows
  • 6 cups Rice Krispies
  • Assorted Sprinkles
  • Small Chocolate Easter Eggs
  • Plastic Easter Eggs

Preparation Instructions

In a large saucepan, melt butter over low heat. Add marshmallows and stir until melted. Remove from heat, then add rice cereal and stir until well coated.

Lightly spray interior of the plastic eggs with non-stick cooking spray. If mixture is too sticky, you can also spray your hands. Fill both sides of the plastic egg with rice cereal mixture, slightly over-filling one side. Press chocolate egg in the center on one side of the egg, then close the plastic egg to shape it. (It should be full enough to meet with a little resistance as you close it.) Gently release the rice cereal egg from the mold, decorate with your choice of sprinkles and set aside in egg crate until set.

Posted by Ree on March 25 2013

item.title: Coolest Bow Ties Ever
item.dc:creator: Ree
item.description: Well, I think these are pretty groovy.       Are you ready?       They’re wooden bow ties.       They’re handmade by two guys (get it?) in Tulsa, Oklahoma.       They use a variety of woods, each one with its own unique grain, and then apply one of a number of patterns to the surface: zig-zag, plaid, etc.       The pics don’t do these justice. They’re truly…
item.content:encoded:
Well, I think these are pretty groovy.

 
 
 
Are you ready?

 
 
 
They’re wooden bow ties.

 
 
 
They’re handmade by two guys (get it?) in Tulsa, Oklahoma.

 
 
 
They use a variety of woods, each one with its own unique grain, and then apply one of a number of patterns to the surface: zig-zag, plaid, etc.

 
 
 
The pics don’t do these justice. They’re truly awesome.

 
 
 
My baby wants to wear one to church on Easter Sunday.

(I’ll encourage him to leave my reading glasses at home.)

 
 
 
I just love these things. Really slick, really sleek, a little bit different, and they’re handmade with love.

 
 
 
The bow ties come in Large…

 
 
 
Or Medium.

 
 
 
And the elastic band fastens with a simple hook. Easy!

And here’s the cool thing: On the website, you can either choose from the bow ties in stock OR you can create a custom bow tie by choosing the wood you want, the etched pattern you want, and the fabric/pattern you want in the center. (I love the plaids.) So much fun!

Here’s the website:

Two Guys Bow Ties

Great Father’s Day or birthday gift for the sharp dresser (or dressers) in your life!

Not an advertisement. Just sharing these awesome bow ties from some local craftsmen.

item.title: COMEDY Movie Quiz: Answers and Winners!
item.dc:creator: Ree
item.description: Great job on the quiz, guys! Here are some stats: * 5,632 people took the quiz. * 1,456 people scored 100% (great job!) * The question most people got right (98% got it right) was…#4 * The question missed the most (only 56% got it right) was…#7. ANSWERS Q.3 In “Trading Places,” what were the wealthy Duke brothers’ first names? Rudolph and Randolph ***Randolph and Mortimer Mortimer and Michael Randolph and Michael      …
item.content:encoded:
Great job on the quiz, guys! Here are some stats:

* 5,632 people took the quiz.
* 1,456 people scored 100% (great job!)
* The question most people got right (98% got it right) was…#4
* The question missed the most (only 56% got it right) was…#7.

ANSWERS

Q.3
In “Trading Places,” what were the wealthy Duke brothers’ first names?

Rudolph and Randolph
***Randolph and Mortimer
Mortimer and Michael
Randolph and Michael

 
 
 
Q.4
In what movie does the Stay Puft Marshmallow Man begin destroying New York City?

Waiting for Guffman
Dirty Rotten Scoundrels
Planes, Trains, and Automobiles
***Ghostbusters

 
 
 
Q.5
“Jim never vomits at home.”

Annie Hall
***Airplane
Anchorman: The Legend of Ron Burgundy
Austin Powers: International Man of Mystery

 
 
 
Q.6
According to Buddy the Elf, the four food groups are candy, candy canes, candy corns and ___________?

Milk chocolate
Peanut butter
Marshmallows
***Syrup

 
 
 
Q.7
In the pro shop in Caddyshack, Rodney Dangerfield says if you buy a hat like Ted Knight’s, you get a free ______________!

Box of tees
***Bowl of soup
Golf lesson
Go
lf cart rental

 
 
 
Q.8
In “Dumb and Dumber,” what does Lloyd spike Harry’s drink with?

Salt
Sleep-All-Nite
Alcohol
***Turbo Lax

 
 
 
Q.9
What is Bill Murray’s occupation in Groundhog Day?

***Meteorologist
Schoolteacher
Dentist
Salesman

 
 
 
Q.10
What is Napoleon Dynamite’s favorite sport?

Volleyball
Bocce Ball
Racquetball
***Tetherball

 
 
 
Q.11
In what movie did Jennifer Aniston’s boss ask her to wear 37 pieces of flair?

Friends With Money
***Office Space
Along Came Polly
She’s the One

 
 
 
Q.12
“Put…zee candle…BACK!”

Dirty Rotten Scoundrels
Trading Places
***Young Frankenstein
Blazing Saddles

 
 
 
Q.13
What was John Belushi’s Delta Tau Chi name in “Animal House?”

***Bluto
Flounder
Pinto
Otter

 
 
 
Q.14
In “Wedding Crashers,” what does Will Ferrell’s character crash?

Baby showers
Bar Mitzvahs
***Funerals
Graduation parties

 
 
 
Q.15
What was significant about the campfire scene in “Blazing Saddles?”

All the cowboys had headaches.
All the cowboys were singing opera.
All the cowboys were wearing rhinestone hats.
***All the cowboys had gas.

 
 
 
Q.16
Who were “on a mission from God?”

Steve Martin and John Candy
***John Belushi and Dan Akroyd
Gene Wilder and Richard Pryor
Eddie Murphy and Dan Akroyd

 
 
 
Q.17
After ordering a new sports wagon, who gets stuck with a Family Truckster?

John Candy
Jim Belushi
Vince Vaughn
***Chevy Chase

 
 
 
Q.18
In “There’s Something About Mary,” what football player plays Mary’s former love interest?

Peyton Manning
John Elway
***Brett Favre
Joe Namath

 
 
 
Q.19
“Brothers don’t shake hands. Brothers gotta hug!”

Wedding Crashers
Dumb & Dumber
***Tommy Boy
Trading Places

 
 
 
Q.20
“Ooooh, behave!”

Ace Ventura
***Austin Powers
Napoleon Dynamite
Buddy the Elf

 

WINNERS

The first person who correctly answered all questions was…Sarah C!
The second place winner (selected from among the first 25 100% scores) was…Karen K!
The third place winner (selected from all 100% scores) was…Marie C!

Congrats, winners! Contact prizes@thepioneerwoman.com to claim your prizes.

item.title: Big COMEDY Movie Quiz: Enter Now!

Important: Select the best possible answer. In some cases, there may arguably be more than one right answer, but there will always be an overwhelmingly/obviously correct answer.   THE PRIZES 1. The first person to correctly answer all questions wins: One (1) 32 GB iPad with…
item.content:encoded:
Time for the big COMEDY movie quiz. Have fun, guys!

 

TO ENTER

To try your hand at the movie quiz, just answer the multiple choice movie questions below.

Important: Select the best possible answer. In some cases, there may arguably be more than one right answer, but there will always be an overwhelmingly/obviously correct answer.

 

THE PRIZES

1. The first person to correctly answer all questions wins:

One (1) 32 GB iPad with a Smart Cover color of his/her choice!

2. One randomly selected player from among the first 25 players to score 100% will receive a second place prize: a $200 Amazon.com gift card.

3. A third place winner will be randomly chosen among all contestants who score 100% and will win a $100 Amazon.com gift card.

Winners/answers will be revealed Sunday.

Good luck! (Quiz may take a moment to load below.)

 
Feel free to shout out your score in the Comments!

Take Our Survey!

item.title: Tomorrow on Zee Food Network: Brunch Food!
item.dc:creator: Ree
item.description: On tomorrow’s Food Network show, I make a big Sunday brunch for the whole family after church…including this luscious ham, which is glazed in an ingredient Marlboro Man gave up for Lent. (You can probably guess what it is.)     I also make drop biscuits (which I featured here recently) and a ridonkulously yummy ham gravy to go over the top.       I also made these eggs…       And this…
item.content:encoded:
On tomorrow’s Food Network show, I make a big Sunday brunch for the whole family after church…including this luscious ham, which is glazed in an ingredient Marlboro Man gave up for Lent.

(You can probably guess what it is.)

 
 
I also make drop biscuits (which I featured here recently) and a ridonkulously yummy ham gravy to go over the top.

 
 
 
I also made these eggs…

 
 
 
And this fruit salad with one of my favorite syrups in the world.

 
 
 
But the star of the whole show are definitely my sister-in-law Missy’s Lemon-Blueberry Cupcakes, which she brought to the brunch that day. They are phenomenally delicious, and completely irresistible! Missy is the cupcake queen.

While the brunch on the show wasn’t on Easter Sunday (it was filmed in the wintertime!) all the food is very Easter Brunch-friendly. I’ll try to post some of the individual recipes here on The Pioneer Woman Cooks in the coming days so you can prepare for next weekend. Meantime, I hope you enjoy the show tomorrow!

Happy Friday, friends.

Love,
P-Widdy

item.title: How do you handle the inherent differences in the way your children learn?
item.dc:creator: OMSH
item.description: By Heather Sanders We homeschool 30 weeks a year, which means we know when we will begin the school year, and most importantly, when it will end. Our school year ends in exactly 6 weeks. I mentioned that bit of trivia to the kids today and received comments like “Six weeks! Summer takes forever to get here!” I have to say I completely agree. Spring Break was not long enough, and Summer feels light years…
item.content:encoded:
By Heather Sanders

We homeschool 30 weeks a year, which means we know when we will begin the school year, and most importantly, when it will end. Our school year ends in exactly 6 weeks. I mentioned that bit of trivia to the kids today and received comments like “Six weeks! Summer takes forever to get here!” I have to say I completely agree. Spring Break was not long enough, and Summer feels light years away. Surprisingly, it is this time of year that makes me the strongest advocate for a structured homeschooling approach; without the structure I am not sure I could find the energy to finish.

For the sake of complete transparency, I debate regularly with a softer, counterintuitive voice in my head that says, “Yes, but if you unschooled, you and the kids would be more personally invested and intrinsically energized while pursuing knowledge in each of your personal areas of interest.”

Then, my louder voice says, “Riiiiiiight. If the kids were given the freedom to choose, they would still not know their multiplication tables.”

And, back and forth this internal conversation plays out until I tire of the confusion and tune out. Am I the only one who deals with this sort of brain babble? It is apparently called “self talk” and if handled correctly, self talk can be a healthy habit. My problem? My “self” won’t shut up.

Sometimes I try to relieve my inner ramblings by taking advantage of Jeff as a sounding board. He’s a tremendous listener, but in the end I’m sure it is nothing short of torture for him. He diligently asks questions that help focus my attention, I make a decision, and then a few hours later the battle rages in my head again.

That is why I stick with structure; for me, it is comfortable, safe, and sure. As a person who thrives on organization and detail, I cannot imagine a school year that didn’t file neatly in a physical binder or digital archive, with each piece of paper or information neatly placed behind subject-specific, labeled dividers or within designated directories.

Thing is the kids’ minds don’t work like mine, which means 1) either my structure is a gift that clears all the unnecessary clutter, ensuring them an unhindered path to their future, or 2) I’m an old school stumbling block that fails to recognize they need to clear their own path to approach their education in a way that best suits how their minds work.

It seems clear that homeschooling is the best, most natural, way for parents to recognize the inherent differences in how each of their children learn. What is less clear is what exactly to do with this knowledge.

These are questions I ponder in this last six weeks of my 7th year of homeschooling, and as you can imagine, the battle rages on in my head. I’m pretty certain I will need a healthy dose of sleeping in and poolside therapy to reach any logical conclusions.

Where are you in this dichotomy of homeschooling styles? What brought you to that place?

 

OMSH/Heather L. Sanders is a wife, mother and friend. She is also a Homeschooling Blogger and Writer. Balance is the challenge she rises to each and every morning.

item.title: What Am I Doing In This Photo?
item.dc:creator: Ree
item.description: First up: This is Matt, one of the two cameramen in the kitchen. He’s often up on the counters getting closeups of the food as I cook, and he provides a steady stream of hilarious one-liners and plays on words, which I need to start writing down so that when I want to post about them, my mind won’t go blank as it is right now. Matt is also married to Olivia, the director, whom…
item.content:encoded:
First up: This is Matt, one of the two cameramen in the kitchen. He’s often up on the counters getting closeups of the food as I cook, and he provides a steady stream of hilarious one-liners and plays on words, which I need to start writing down so that when I want to post about them, my mind won’t go blank as it is right now.

Matt is also married to Olivia, the director, whom I absolutely love. She is the calm and sweet yin to Matt’s mischievous and comedic yang, and I love being in the kitchen with the two English pookie lovebirds.

That said, I didn’t know they were married until the second time they came for a shoot. They keep it under wraps!

Get it? Wraps?

(I think all this TV terminology is getting to me.)

And speaking of wraps, doesn’t that word alone sum up all that is wrong with the English language?

Wrap – verb. To cover or enclose something. I’m going to wrap my arms around Marlboro Man’s chiseled waist when I see him tonight.

Wrap – verb. To finish filming.
Okay, that’s it—time to wrap for the day! Time to go home and watch Real Housewives, Ree.

Wrap – noun. The end of filming.
Okay, that’s a wrap! Time to go home and pick your toenails, Ree.

Wrap – noun. A loose outer garment.
Can I take your wrap to the coat room?

Wrap – noun. A veil of secrecy.
Olivia and Matt keep their marriage under wraps while they’re working.

Wrap – noun. A sandwich rolled inside a tortilla or flatbread.
Have you tried my chicken marshmallow chili veggie chocolate wrap?

And don’t even get me started on rap.

Stop the madness!

 
 
On another note, Matt snapped this photo of me yesterday.

Hey! Pop Quiz!

 

What Am I Doing In This Photo?

(More shoot updates to come! Thanks for bearing with my weird daily journal.)

(UPDATE: I was filing a rough edge on one of my fingernails after nicking it with a knife! I have mad skilz that way.)

item.title: Did You Go to Prom? (Winners!)
item.dc:creator: Ree
item.description: The winners of the gorgeous Indigo pots are: #7423 Adam: “Went to a very small school that did not do a prom. We all went out to eat at a restaurant instead.” #26181 Becca: “Yes I did! I wore a beautiful blue satin formal (with a lace-covered bodice to hide my sweaty underarms) that my mother made…” Congratulations, winners! Contact prizes@thepioneerwoman.com to claim your new pot. Today, because I’ve just got a few days of…
item.content:encoded:
The winners of the gorgeous Indigo pots are:

#7423 Adam: “Went to a very small school that did not do a prom. We all went out to eat at a restaurant instead.”
#26181 Becca: “Yes I did! I wore a beautiful blue satin formal (with a lace-covered bodice to hide my sweaty underarms) that my mother made…”

Congratulations, winners! Contact prizes@thepioneerwoman.com to claim your new pot.

Today, because I’ve just got a few days of shooting left…

Because I’m making French Dips today…

Because my tulips are coming up…

And because I love ya…

 
I’m giving away two (2) of these Le Creuset 7 1/4 Quart French Ovens in this gorgeous new “Indigo” color.

 
 
This is a bee-yoo-tee-ful blue color: really deep and dramatic. And blue!

 

TO ENTER

To enter this giveaway, just answer the following questions in the Comments section of this post:

“Did you go to your high school prom?”

Prom season is just around the corner, so let’s hear it: Did you attend your high school prom? Or did you skip it in favor of something more simple, like a night of Betamax movies and Orville Redenbacher popcorn?

Just shout out whether you went to prom (and any fun details, if you wish) and you’re automatically entered to win a Le Creuset. (If you’d rather not say, just shout out anything along the lines of “Howdy!” or “I love blue!” and you’re automatically entered to win.)

THE RULES

One entry per person, please.

Winners will be announced Friday!

item.title: Day Five
item.dc:creator: Ree
item.description: Housekeeping Matter: Monday I launched a couple of tweaks to my website, which turned out to have some incompatibilities with Internet Explorer. It should be fixed in just a bit; let me know later today if you’re still seeing wonky behavior. (From my website. Not from me. If you see wonky behavior from me, there’s nothing wrong with your computer. That’s just normal.) In other news, thank you for letting me take you along on…
item.content:encoded:
Housekeeping Matter: Monday I launched a couple of tweaks to my website, which turned out to have some incompatibilities with Internet Explorer. It should be fixed in just a bit; let me know later today if you’re still seeing wonky behavior. (From my website. Not from me. If you see wonky behavior from me, there’s nothing wrong with your computer. That’s just normal.)

In other news, thank you for letting me take you along on my shooting experiences this week! It’s fun to continue to share what I’m doing with you, even if what I’m doing is a little wacky.

 
This is David, who has worked on the show almost since the beginning. In the photo above, he’s showing me a photo of his niece and her baby, whom he clearly adores. He, along with my good friend Tiffany (who’s nearly seven months pregnant right now, which is making me have all sorts of gestational thoughts) make sure all the food is in place for every recipe I cook on the show. It’s a huge job and requires a lot of coordination, especially considering we live in the country and can’t just run out and pick up something we don’t have.

Um…welcome to my daily life?

And David lives in New York City, which makes the contrast all the more stark for him.

David, it turns out, actually loves our small town and appreciates the time he gets to spend here. Last year, probably because he’s there every single morning of the shoot, David won ten dollars from our local grocery store as part of a fun promotion they were having that involved daily drawings for different cash prizes. Because he won, they took his picture and put it on the wall of winners in the store.

This was a highlight of David’s experience here. He still talks about it like it was a complete honor.

I love that guy.

 
 
This is Mike, one of the Marmalade Men. He’s snapping stills of some of the food I made yesterday.

 
 
 
I packed up box lunches and headed in to The Building to meet with Marlboro Man, my mother-in-law, and our contractors, who are putting in the windows. The cameras walked all over the building and got to get a lot of “before” shots.

 
 
 
There was lots of miscellaneous cooking going on yesterday, including this…

 
 
 
And this.

Oh, dear.

Just you wait, ‘enry ‘iggins!

Name that movie.

 
 
 
Then it was time to make brownies, so the director Olivia and I talked through the recipe beforehand and discussed the best way to proceed.

And this is something you might not know about cooking shows: It would be difficult to show up, tell the cameramen “I’m making brownies today, guys. Ready, set, go!” because they’d wind up with a lot of missed shots of the food and the process, and the end result wouldn’t be as visually appealing (or as complete). So we make sure to have the recipe broken up into logical pieces, and then we make sure the cameramen know which direction the ingredients are going to head, then Mike makes sure all the lights will bring out the natural beauty of the food, then I run powder my face for the four thousandth time because it’s already shiny again.

Then I grab a cracker and a Diet Dr Pepper.

Then I run to the ladies room. But I take my mic off first.

 
 
 
Then it’s brownie time!

 
 
 
I get them baked and iced, then I snap a photo.

 
 
 
Then I go around to the other side of the counter and snap a photo. Doesn’t this kind of look like aliens kidnapped me?

Has anyone seen Ree for awhile?…

What you also can’t see in this photo is the inch-thick layer of powdered sugar on the floor underneath my work station.

It’s there because—well, because I’m messy, but also because when I’m addressing the camera and cooking or baking something, I can’t always hunker over and contort my body to get ingredients to go into vessels without also falling all over the floor. Pay attention next time you cook something by yourself: You might find yourself leaning over, wrapping your arm around your mixer so as to get the powdered sugar to drop in without going everywhere, making weird faces as you concentrate on chopping, etc. Now imagine a camera is there, and you need to somewhat clearly narrate every step you’re doing, and not look like a complete dodo bird while you do it.

Makes you want to stand up a little straighter and remember not to scratch your armpit, I’ll tell you that.

 
 
 
Before I could get a chance, David came along and de-powdered sugared the floor. Thank you, David!

My shoes were starting to make sticky sounds when I walked.

I’m super neat that way.

 
 
 
Not that this guy minds. What David doesn’t whisk away, Charlie can always count as a mid-afternoon snack.

 
 
 
It goes without saying that I highly recommend having a Basset Hound nearby if you ever find yourself shooting a cooking show. They’re a more powerful cleaning tool than any Swifter in the universe.

(Unless you count all the grass they bring in from outside. But that’s just a technicality.)

item.title: Old Friends, New Friends, and Cameras
item.dc:creator: Ree
item.description: We had friends over to The Lodge for dinner Saturday night: Hyacinth and her family (our friends for many years), Steve and Sheila (our friends for many years), and Steve’s brother Mike and his family, who just moved to our small town last year. Mike and Steve actually grew up here, and Steve has lived here since he finished college. Mike and his wife Bev recently decided to move back to Pawhuska after Mike and…
item.content:encoded:
We had friends over to The Lodge for dinner Saturday night: Hyacinth and her family (our friends for many years), Steve and Sheila (our friends for many years), and Steve’s brother Mike and his family, who just moved to our small town last year. Mike and Steve actually grew up here, and Steve has lived here since he finished college. Mike and his wife Bev recently decided to move back to Pawhuska after Mike and Steve’s dad passed away, and while Mike and Steve and their families go to our church, Marlboro Man and I have been wanting to have them all out for dinner for awhile.

Did that make any sense at all? I sure know how to give a thorough explanation, don’t I?

Or not.

 
It just so happened that we had them over for dinner while the TV crew was here.

Before I had the experience of being on a television show, I would have thought a scene like the one above—one that involves socializing and visiting with friends while cameras are watching—would feel strange and unnatural. But in fact, it becomes really easy to just forget they’re there. This is largely due to the crew itself; they’re quiet and pretty unobtrusive. But also, it helps when the events they’re chronicling are real life events, as Saturday evening’s dinner was. We were so excited to finally have Mike and Bev (and their son Marshall) over to the house, our conversation with them overrode any awareness of cameras being pointed up our nostrils.

At one point, our director Olivia quietly said, “Whenever you’re ready, you guys can head to the table and tuck in.” Tuck in, in England, means to dig in and start eating.

I noticed out of the corner of my eye that our guest Mike was looking down at his shirt and tucking it in a bit.

I got a chuckle out of that one.

 
 
 
And it’s not just me being used to cameras because I’ve been doing it for awhile. Our guests were there just five minutes before they were mingling and enjoying the conversation, hardly glancing in the direction of the cameras at all.

 
 
 
On a slightly separate note, before the crew arrived for this block of shows, I looked at the range area here at the Lodge and realized I hadn’t changed anything there for probably nine hundred years. The same olive oil bottle, the same salt and pepper pots, the same lamp and utensil crock and weird almost-empty jar of peppercorns into which one of my boys had placed some peanuts (don’t ask) were there, staring at me and saying “Change me.” So I took everything off, put everything away, and we started over. I didn’t want it to look too “done” with big pots of fresh flowers and colorful vases. I just wanted it to look normal, and to have all the stuff there that I needed to cook so I wouldn’t have to walk two feet to the cabinets, because I’m lazy.

 
 
 
Dinner was nice. Hyacinth loved getting to know Mike and Bev.

 
 
 
Hy’s almost-college-graduate was home from school, so he came along too. Hi, Matthew! I knew you when you were nine.

 
 
 
Mike enjoyed my psychotic four-layer cake.

 
 
 
Ha.

 
 
 
Instead of a kids’ table, we did a teenagers’ table! They were fine with it, until I remembered that I forgot to put food up there for them.

I remembered, because four teenagers were sitting at their seats, banging their forks on the counter.

 
 
 
My baby was excited to get to sit with the adults.

He’s an old soul, that one.

No, really. I estimate his soul is about 82.

 
 
 
In closing: Photobomb!

Okay, that’s all for now. We all had a really good time at the dinner—cameras and all—and everyone went home full and happy.

I’ll give you more behind-the-scenes action tomorrow! I’m snapping pics all day today.

item.title: Children’s Wallet Cards – Review & Giveaway (Winners Announced!)
item.dc:creator: OMSH
item.category: Art AppreciationContributorsEnglish/LiteratureForeign LanguageGiveawaysHomeschooling MaterialsLanguage ArtsMathMiscellaneousOMSHPhonics/LettersPre-KChildren's ABC Cardseducational cardKickstarterlearning numberspre-k manipulatives
item.description: The three winners of the Children’s Wallet Cards – Review & Giveaway are: #525 Julie in Bridgewater: “It would be hard to pick one…alphabet, colors and shapes or number… have a nine month old granddaughter so any would be great to have! Thanks.” #188 Chrissy B: “My son is currently obsessed with numbers, everything must be counted. He would be thrilled with the numbers set.” #915 Cynthia: “I think my children (2,4) would most enjoy…
item.content:encoded:
The three winners of the Children’s Wallet Cards – Review & Giveaway are:

#525 Julie in Bridgewater: “It would be hard to pick one…alphabet, colors and shapes or number… have a nine month old granddaughter so any would be great to have! Thanks.”

#188 Chrissy B: “My son is currently obsessed with numbers, everything must be counted. He would be thrilled with the numbers set.”

#915 Cynthia: “I think my children (2,4) would most enjoy the ABC deck. Followed closely by the colors.”

Congratulations, winners! Contact heather@omsh.com to claim your FREE set of the Children’s ABC Wallet Cards!

The Kickstarter campaign to raise monies for the production of the 4 additional decks is still underway. Don’t forget to check it out!

——————

By Heather Sanders.

Last summer a reader here pointed me toward Marie-Claire Camp’s Kickstarter campaign to develop a set of uniquely designed, wallet-size ABC cards for children. Though my own children are beyond the age for these cards, I backed the project anyway. The project reached its goal with the help of 376 backers and I received the cards just in time to gift them to my cousin’s children for Christmas.

Vividly illustrated by Australian artist Marc Martin, the Children’s Alphabet cards are as indestructible as they are educational.

It was exciting to watch the original project draw near its funding goal as each new backer placed their pledge.

And though I do not personally know Camp, I felt an attachment to the success of the campaign, which is why I wanted to let you know she has launched a second Kickstarter campaign with the hope of funding the development of four additional decks of children’s cards: Numbers, GO!, Color & Shape, and My Wallet.

Just as with the original Children’s ABC Deck, these cards will be extremely durable, BPA free, recyclable, and designed on FDA-approved, food-grade, non-toxic plastic. The ink will also be non-toxic, food-safe ink. Each deck will be illustrated by a different artist.

My personal favorite is the Numbers deck, illustrated by Eugene & Louise, a Belgium based creative studio founded by husband and wife, Glenn D’Hondt and Sylvia Meert.

The GO! deck, illustrated by Jared Andrew Schorr, shows images of people moving in exciting ways, (e.g. skateboarding, hang-gliding, and skiing).

London artist Nomoco will create the artwork for the Color & Shape cards. Watercolor and ink illustrations will represent common colors and shapes.

The final My Wallet card set is a wallet that holds a license, a bank card, a children’s museum membership card and a library card. Also included is play money printed on durable Tyvek. A free iOS app, Digital Toys, will pair with each card’s theme.

Camp’s original inspiration came from her boys pulling apart her wallet and scoping out all her cards. These four cards mimic what can be found in an adult wallet, but are durable and safe for child’s play.

If you participated in the original campaign, then you know how valuable these cards are for parents of young children. They are available in 7 retail locations and are now available online as well.

When Camp raises the money she needs to Kickstart this ambitious campaign, there will be more than 40 additional pieces of amazing original artwork from three separate artists to secure on the carabiner-style ring that houses the original collection.

Learn more about this Kickstarter campaign by clicking on the video above. Or, join this stay-at-home Mom’s vision by making a pledge or visiting the project page. Remember, at Kickstarter no funding is debited from any backer’s account unless the project goal is reached in its entirety.

This project launched on February 27,2013 and has 10 days to go (March 29, 2013). So far it has 137 backers and $8,780 raised toward a $24,950 goal. There are different reward levels for pledges based on the amount pledged, but as the project states, even $1.00 will help.

HERE’S THREE LUCKY WINNERS’ CHANCE TO WIN ONE (1) SET OF CHILDREN’S ABC CARDS

I love the Children’s ABC Cards and you will too. Marie-Claire Camp is giving away one (1) set of Children’s ABC Cards to three (3) lucky winners!

HERE’S HOW TO ENTER
To enter the giveaway, just answer the following question in the Comments section below.

Which of the four new decks would your child be most interested in and why?

THE RULES
One entry per person, please.
Entries must live within the Continental United States.
No entries after noon (CST) On Wednesday, the 20th.
Winner will be selected at random and announced soon after.

THANKS FOR PARTICIPATING! COMMENTS ARE CLOSED – THE WINNERS ARE ANNOUNCED AT THE TOP!!

____________________________________________________

Please note: As I stated in the previous Kickstarter campaign, I am in no way associated with this venture and receive nothing for writing about it. However, I enjoyed giving the original cards as gifts to my 2nd cousins and they have enjoyed them immensely, so I would love to see this project get funded.
____________________________________________________

 

OMSH/Heather L. Sanders is a wife, mother and friend. She is also a Homeschooling Blogger and Writer. Balance is the challenge she rises to each and every morning.

item.title: My Top Nine Favorite Eagles Songs, In Order
item.dc:creator: Ree
item.description: I’m not sure what compelled him to do this, but Marlboro Man recently DVR’d a documentary about The Eagles that aired on Showtime. The other night, after we watched a couple of our regular TV shows, he turned it on and said “Let’s watch this.” I wasn’t all that enthused, as it’s over three hours long and a documentary about a rock band didn’t hold much appeal to me that night. It turned out to…
item.content:encoded:
I’m not sure what compelled him to do this, but Marlboro Man recently DVR’d a documentary about The Eagles that aired on Showtime. The other night, after we watched a couple of our regular TV shows, he turned it on and said “Let’s watch this.” I wasn’t all that enthused, as it’s over three hours long and a documentary about a rock band didn’t hold much appeal to me that night.

It turned out to be one of the best things I’ve watched in a long, long time.

The documentary is “History of the Eagles,” and has been airing on Showtime. It takes you through the earliest days of Don Henley and Glenn Frey (did you know they played backup for Linda Ronstadt?) and chronicles, through home movies, concert footage, photos, and interviews, the evolution of The Eagles, from inception to fame to breakup to solo careers to reunion.

I can’t even begin to tell you everything that’s wonderful about it. It’s so rich in rock-and-roll history, and every song that began playing made me close my eyes and think “Ahhhh…” They gave me a peaceful, easy feeling.

(Sorry.)

Just a few things I learned:

* I can not choose between Don Henley and Glenn Frey. I love both their voices equally, and my favorite songs are a mix of Don and Glenn-led tunes.

* I love seventies rock.

* Honestly, when the documentary came to the point of the Eagles’ breakup, I marveled that they lasted as long as they did. I don’t know how a band sustains that kind of pace and night-after-night energy. I think they should have just called it a break instead of a breakup, because that’s exactly what they deserved. They’d put in a lot of time.

* And no. None of it was wasted. (Get it?)

* I enjoyed and appreciated both Glenn Frey’s and Don Henley’s solo careers, but I prefer them as part of the group. Somehow they shine even brighter together.

* I love Joe Walsh. He’s so fun to watch. Whoa…the talent.

* I love Timothy B. Schmidt, who joined the Eagles in 1977. He has a great voice. And attitude. Such a kind spirit.

* I know his Eagles run didn’t end well, but Don Felder’s solos were amazing, and again—so fun to watch. d

* I hated watching the strife and arguments, but how could a band (containing so many creatively-driven people) be together that long without a couple of cracks forming?

* How many hit songs can one band have?

* Their songs take my back to my youth like few others.

* One of my favorite moments in the documentary was when Don Henley was remarking about all the speculation surrounding the “true meaning” of “Hotel California.” He said he’d always been confused about the wild theories because (I’m paraphrasing) Hotel California “…is about the transition from innocent to experience. Nothing more.”

That’s all for now. I see that History of the Eagles is coming out on DVD April 30. I highly recommend it if you want to be taken back in time and experience the story of one of the greatest bands of all time.

Here’s more information:

History of the Eagles

And here are my favorite Eagles songs, in order.

 

MY TOP NINE FAVORITE EAGLES SONGS OF ALL TIME

1. Peaceful, Easy Feeling

“I like the way your sparkling earrings lay against your skin so brown…”

2. Take it Easy

“It’s a girl, my Lord, in a flatbed Ford slowin’ down to take a look at me…”

3. Tequila Sunrise

“He was just a hired hand, workin’ on a dream he planned to try…”

4. Take it to the Limit

“So put me on a highway, show me a sign…”

5. Desperado

“It may be rainin’, but there’s a rainbow above you…you’d better let somebody love you before it’s too late…”

6. Already Gone

“Well, I heard some people talkin’ just the other day…and they said you were gonna put me on a shelf…”

7. Lyin’ Eyes

“She drives on through the night anticipating…’cause he makes her feel the way she used to feel…”

8. Wasted Time

“And maybe someday we will find…that it wasn’t really wasted time…”

9. Hotel California

“You can check out any time you’d like…but you can never leave…”

Feel free to shout out yours!

item.title: Makeup Organizers
item.dc:creator: Ree
item.description: I’m shooting more episodes of the show right now, and since I’m doing my own makeup I had to improve upon my previous makeup-organizing program, which has pretty much been me throwing every makeup item I own into a square wicker basket and rummaging through it anytime I needed to find an eyeliner or lipstick. Something had to give, so I found these large makeup organizers from The Container Store, and while I always thought…
item.content:encoded:
I’m shooting more episodes of the show right now, and since I’m doing my own makeup I had to improve upon my previous makeup-organizing program, which has pretty much been me throwing every makeup item I own into a square wicker basket and rummaging through it anytime I needed to find an eyeliner or lipstick. Something had to give, so I found these large makeup organizers from The Container Store, and while I always thought lucite/acrylic was a thing of the eighties, I couldn’t pass up how handy all the different slots looked.

They’re turning out to be lifesavers, providing a place for everything from powder to hair clips. It cuts down on time because everything’s right in front of me, and it keeps me from saying “Ugh! Where is my beige iridescent LIPSTICK?!?” (Name that movie) every ten minutes.

I think they’ve actually added 1.3 years to my life.

 
 
 
In addition to the larger organizers above, I also found this.

 
 
 
I love it. It holds all the pencils, brushes, and little tools…and holds quite a bit!

 
 
 
These would also be great for toothbrushes, etc., by the bathroom sink…or even in an office setting for pencils, pens, rulers, etc.

Here are the links for the two different organizers! The large one is a little pricey, but looks to be pretty darn durable and holds a ton of stuff. (Note: I have more than one in the photo above, but you really can cram a lot of items into one.)

Large Makeup Organizer (The lipstick section is removable, which is handy.)

Tubo Countertop Organizer

(Warning: Enter The Container Store at your own risk! It sucks you in.)

Not an advertisement. Just sharing something groovy, man.

item.title: Mixed Berry Shortcake
item.dc:creator: Ree
item.description: It’s Monday! It’s a brand new week! The birds are chirping! The coffee’s brewing! Everything has such hope and promise! And here’s why: The utter horror—the abject hopelessness—of springing forward is finally behind us. Man, was this year a toughie. I didn’t think I was going to make it there for a minute. The first part of last week, I felt like a combination of zombie, sloth, nitwit, dodo bird, and koala bear. I couldn’t…
item.content:encoded:
It’s Monday! It’s a brand new week! The birds are chirping! The coffee’s brewing! Everything has such hope and promise!

And here’s why: The utter horror—the abject hopelessness—of springing forward is finally behind us.

Man, was this year a toughie. I didn’t think I was going to make it there for a minute. The first part of last week, I felt like a combination of zombie, sloth, nitwit, dodo bird, and koala bear. I couldn’t think, move, think, function, or remember the Macarena.

But slowly, as the week went on, things slowly improved. By the weekend, it became clear to me that I was going to live. And to celebrate, yesterday I made a round of berry shortcakes for the everyone! It felt so good to be back.

You’ll love this shortcake recipe. I used a sweet version of the drop biscuits I made in last week’s Biscuit and Sausage Gravy post, then I whipped up some syrupy berries and topped the whole thing with an unimaginably delectable sweet yogurt cream, which should come with a warning label, it’s so addictive.

Make this sometime this week, my friends! It’s a treat that’ll make you smile.

 

BISCUITS

 
To make the biscuits, add flour to the bowl of a food processor (or just throw it violently into a bowl if you want to make the biscuits by hand.)

 
 
 
Add some baking powder…

 
 
 
Sugar, because I want the biscuits to be a little on the sweet side.

But just a little.

 
 
 
And a leetle bit of salt.

But just a leetle.

 
 
 
Then just pulse the dry ingredients a couple of times.

 
 
 
Add a stick-and-a-half of really cold butter cut into pieces…

 
 
 
Then do 25 to 30 really short pulses to work the butter into the dry ingredients.

 
 
 
Measure the buttermilk, then stir in a little bit of almond extract. This is entirely optional and does give the biscuits a hint of almond flavor, which I love. But you could leave it out (or substitute vanilla) if you prefer.

 
 
 
Slowly drizzle the mixture into the food processor, pulsing the whole time…

 
 
 
Until it all comes together in a clump.

 
 
 
Use two spoons to drop small piles of dough onto a baking sheet, then bake ‘em for 15 minutes or so, until they’re just light and golden brown.

Then take ‘em out of the oven and let ‘em cool.

 

BERRIES

 
Next, move onto the berries. I used blackberries…

 
 
 
Raspberries…

 
 
 
Blueberries…

 
 
 
And strawberries.

 
 
 
I added sugar so the berries would have a nice syrup…

 
 
 
Then I zested a Cute/clementine, because I didn’t have any oranges or lemons! And there’s nothing worse! Than needing a lemon! And not having one!

I was going to add lemon zest to the biscuit dough, but I’ll have to do it next time.

 
 
 
Sliced the Cute in half…

 
 
 
Squeezed in the juice…

 
 
 
Then tossed ‘em around.

 
 
 
You can also make a bowl of just strawberries if you like the original.

 

SWEET YOGURT CREAM

 
Now for the sweet yogurt cream, which is going to change your life.

 
 
 
Add a package of Greek yogurt to the mixer…

 
 
 
Then add a half-pint of cream…

 
 
 
A half a cup of sugar…

 
 
 
A couple of tablespoons of brown sugar…

 
 
 
Then whip it on high until it’s stiff. It won’t be stiff like regular whipped cream, but it’ll be thick and silky…and just wait till you taste it.

 

SERVE IT UP

 
When you’re ready to serve it all up…

 
 
 
Pour on the syrupy berries…

 
 
 
Then add a nice big dollop of yogurt cream.

 
 
 
Beauty on a plate!

And in my mouth.

 
 
 
You know what’s good? This.

 
 
 
I shared it with my oldest child and we both enjoyed every dang bite.

 
 
 
Here’s the strawberry version.

 
 
 
Nummy num num num. NUM!

 
 
 
Oh! And you can do this if you want, but it winds up being a whole lotta biscuit. It’s best to make the biscuits much smaller if you want this presentation.

 
 
 
Enjoy, my friends!

Here’s the handy dandy printable.

Recipe

Mixed Berry Shortcake

Prep Time:
15 Minutes
Cook Time:
15 Minutes
Difficulty:
Easy
Servings:
8
Print Recipe

Ingredients

  • Biscuits
  • 3 cups All-purpose Flour
  • 2 Tablespoons Baking Powder
  • 3 Tablespoons Sugar
  • 1/2 teaspoon Salt
  • 1-1/2 stick (3/4 Cup) Cold Butter, Cut Into Pieces
  • 1-1/4 cup Buttermilk
  • 1/2 teaspoon Almond Extract (optional)
  • Berries
  • 2 pints Mixed Berries And/or Sliced Strawberries
  • 1/3 cup Sugar
  • Zest And Juice Of 1 Small Orange
  • SWEET YOGURT CREAM
  • 1 package (7 Ounces) Plain Greek Yogurt
  • 1 cup Cold Heavy Cream
  • 1/2 cup Sugar
  • 2 Tablespoons Brown Sugar

Preparation Instructions

BISCUITS

Preheat oven to 400 degrees.

Add flour, baking powder, sugar, and salt to the bowl of a food processor (or a large bowl.) Add butter pieces and pulse until butter is completely cut into the flour mixture (or use a pastry cutter if using a bowl.) Add almond extract to buttermilk. While pulsing (or stirring) drizzle in the buttermilk until dough just comes together and is no longer crumbly.

Drop in clumps on two baking sheets, then bake for 15 minutes, or until golden brown. Set aside and allow to cool completely.

BERRIES

Wash berries (slice strawberries if using) and place into a bowl. Sprinkle on 1/3 cup sugar, then add orange zest and juice. Stir gently, then set aside for 15 to 20 minutes to allow syrup to develop.

CREAM

In the bowl of an electric mixer fitted with the whisk attachment, whip yogurt, cream, sugar, and brown sugar on high until stiff (note: It won't get quite as stiff as regular whipped cream.)

TO SERVE

To serve, lay one biscuit on a plate, top with syrupy fruit, then top with a good spoonful of cream.

Posted by Ree on March 18 2013

item.title: Productivity Apps for Homeschooling Moms?
item.dc:creator: OMSH

Email it to OMSH. *********************************************** The following question is from Meriam B. “I recently purchased an iPad. We have downloaded lots of educational apps, but I was wondering if there were any good productivity apps…
item.content:encoded:
Community Question is a category inspired by you. Here and there readers write in with questions that are better served by the varied, experiential knowledge of those who read and contribute in the comments. Have a question for the community? Email it to OMSH.

***********************************************

The following question is from Meriam B.

“I recently purchased an iPad. We have downloaded lots of educational apps, but I was wondering if there were any good productivity apps for homeschooling moms and teachers for grade recording, attendance records, lesson planning, etc. I’d really like some ways to help me be a better, more organized teacher.

Do you use any type of productivity apps to help you organize your homeschool?
